learning_outcomes.description: Understand how texts engage and shape the concerns and anxieties of the period in which they are written.
Be able to position texts in relation to prevailing intellectual traditions.
Understand the contested nature of 'the Enlightenment' as a period and process.
Be able to evaluate competing interpretations of a text.
Be able to use evidence to construct arguments.
Appreciate issues related to working in translation.

assessments.due_date:
Please note that there are NO opportunities to re-take individual quizzes. And there is no alternative assessment available unless you have a Disability Action Plan that applies to the quiz. Accommodations in the tutorial can be made for many of the issues documented in Disability Action Plans (e.g. if you cannot handwrite exams).  


If a student has a genuine (documented) reason why they have been unable to attend more than 3 quizzes, then a make-up quiz will be arranged late in semester that covers all texts and lectures and will be worth 35%. Typically the only reason that justifies the make-up is sudden/serious illness that requires a lengthy absence. Work commitments are not a valid reason.
assessments.task_description:
In Week 1, each student will be allocated a week for which they will develop discussion questions with a group of students from other tutorials. 

This will involve:

  1. Producing one comprehension question that can be answered by reading and understanding the text (the question should be neither easy nor perplexing) and one interpretive question that engages the logic of the text's argument/plot;  
  2. Producing an answer sheet that states the essential elements of a correct answer to the comprehension question (see the Locke template on Blackboard in the Group Work assessment folder);
  3. Independently verifying the comprehension answer to show its correctness; and producing a group response to the interpretive question that summarises the Zoom discussion;
  4. Submitting a link to a Zoom/Teams recording of the group meeting where you:

i) discuss the verification and seriously discuss whether the comprehension question and answer need to be adjusted;

ii) evaluate the final questions/answers and agree that they were feasible and accurate (see 3) and try to formulate a collective position on the interpretive question, noting the core disagreement where this is not possible;

iii) agree that the submission is of a good standard and note any issues regarding individual contributions that may warrant an individual's grade being adjusted.

5. Submitting 1-4 as a single document to Turnitin before Friday 2pm of the week before the text is discussed in seminars.


Note: login using your UQ account and select record to the Cloud, then copy this link and include it in your submission. 

Help finding the link: https://support.zoom.com/hc/en/article?id=zm_kb&sysparm_article=KB0067567#:~:text=Sign%20in%20to%20the%20Zoom,the%20meeting%20ID%20or%20topic.

(Alternatively, use dropbox or Teams and add a link to your submission but the key point is to record to the Cloud and not to a local drive).
assessments.submission_guidelines: One submission per group. (Use the link for any member of the group and use the text's title as the submission title.)
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

Please note that there are NO opportunities to re-take individual quizzes. And there is no alternative assessment available unless you have a Disability Action Plan that applies to the quiz. Accommodations in the tutorial can be made for many of the issues documented in Disability Action Plans (e.g. if you cannot handwrite exams).  


If a student has a genuine (documented) reason why they have been unable to attend more than 3 quizzes, then a make-up quiz will be arranged late in semester that covers all texts and lectures and will be worth 35%. assessments.task_description:
In Weeks 3-12, there will be 10 closed-book quizzes administered in tutorials (sometimes at the beginning of the tute, sometimes at the end, sometimes in the middle). Each quiz will consist of 5 questions that relate to the text being discussed in tutorials for that week and to the lecture on that text. The answers will be short, usually 1-3 words, and each question is worth 1 mark. (In rare cases, 1/2 marks will be awarded for partially correct answers.) The quiz will only last for 5 minutes.


Your grade is determied by your best 7 scores. I.e. students may miss 3 tutorials and simply let their grade rest with 7 scores. Or, students may take all quizzes and thereby improve their grade. Note: the quizzes run all the way through until Week 12 when students are typically under pressure from other assessments, i.e. if you are a student who is likely to skip some tutorials, then don't skip the early tutes!


Note II: It's important that you always read the full JAC instance (easiest by clicking "Course Profile" on Blackboard). This is because the publicly-visible versions (not accessed via Learn.UQ or mySI-net) will simply state under Criteria & Marking "UQ Students: Please access the profile from Learn.UQ or mySI-net to access marking criteria held in this profile." In other words, you will not see the full task description!
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: Produce a Plan for your research presentation that follows the template provided on Blackboard in the Assessment folder.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date: Presentations will be held during Exam Week 1. Students will be able to nominate a time from several days via a sign-up sheet that will be released close to the time. This time is then treated as the presentation/exam date.
assessments.task_description:
During Exam Week 1, you will present your research Report (1000w) that compares and contrasts the accounts of enlightenment developed by two thinkers in this course (see the model on Blackboard). Ideally, this will build on the provisional research in your Plan, but if you want to change direction then that is fine. (A comparison of Locke and Pufendorf is excluded as a possible topic since this is the subject of the model.)

Bring two hardcopies of your Report on the day, one to give to the marker. (You will need to submit a copy to Turnitin on the same day so that the wordcount can be verified.) You will then walk the examiner through your argument (6-8 minutes; an alarm will sound at 7 minutes). You should be prepared to answer short questions along the way.

This presentation is a pass/fail hurdle (50%) that ensures that the course's learning objectives have been achieved. The oral response will be recorded. The quality of your speech (i.e. eloquence) forms no part of the grade or marking process, which rests solely on the quality of your arguments not the manner of their presentation. Criteria are available on Blackboard.

If the student receives less than 50%, then an overall grade of 3 is awarded for the course (marginal fail or ‘S’ = Supplementary) for the course. The student can apply for a supplementary assessment (see Assessment Procedure – Section 3 Part J).


Research Tips:

  1. It will be important to clarify the target of enlightenment to yourself, e.g. individual, society, state, nation, ruling elite, masses, or whatever, as this will likely be crucial to the comparison. 
  2. Carefully reading and mastering your primary sources is the major burden that the task imposes, not the actual writing, so adjust your work timetable accordingly! Secondary texts should only be used sparingly and excellent presentations may not use them at all.
  3. As you will practise in tutorials, this task requires treating the original language and its meaning with historical sensitivity. For example, if you translate Locke's "property in his own person" into "liberal rights" then you have not handled his text with historical sensitivity!


This assessment task evaluates student’s abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Visit the AI Student Hub for essential information on understanding and using Artificial Intelligence in your studies responsibly.
assessments.submission_guidelines: See Blackboard for a model answer and marking criteria. Students will select a time in Exam Week 1 to meet with the examiner, bringing two hardcopies of their Report. They will then walk the examiner through the Report (6-8 minutes), answering clarifying questions along the way that demonstrate attainment of the core learning outcomes. Note: all marks are awarded for the content, i.e. how well you speak does not affect your grade. Students who do not show that they have achieved the core learning outcomes (via at least a grade of 50%) will fail the Hurdle and receive a "3" for the overall course.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
